newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: UOB Foreign sinks to six-month low.
newsitem.headline: UOB Foreign sinks to six-month low.

text.p: Foreign tranches of United Overseas Bank Ltd (UOB) led losers on Monday and sunk to a six-month low, dampened by weak general market sentiment, dealers and analysts said.
It lost Singapore $0.70 to S$13.40 on active volume of about 1.5 million shares.
The shares were last traded around current levels on October 22 when it ended at S$13.20.
"UOB has always been an indicator of U.S. fund movement into the Singapore market," said Vasu Menon, research manager at Keppel Securities Ltd.
Analysts agreed the stock had always had a strong following among foreign funds, notably U.S. fund managers due to its attractive pricing relative to other local banks listed in Singapore.

They said the sell-off was triggered by the overall weakness in the Singapore market, which saw the benchmark Straits Times Industrials Index plunge below 2,000 for the first time since September 1993.
The index ended down 22.81 points or 1.13 percent at 1,996.79.
Analysts said at current levels, UOB Foreign was a good buy.
"It has the lowest price earning ratio compared to the foreign tranches of other banks," Menon said.
